newsitem.title: USA: Clinton calls on American, pilots to reach accord. [CORRECTED 3:22 GMT 13/2]
newsitem.headline: Clinton calls on American, pilots to reach accord. [CORRECTED 3:22 GMT 13/2]

text.p: President Bill Clinton Wednesday said a strike by American Airlines' pilots would have "huge implications" for the nation and urged both sides to use federally mediated talks to avert a walkout.

"Today I want to say that the time has not expired, and I want to encourage parties to make maximum use of the mediation board process. That's what ought to be done today," Clinton told reporters at a White House event on aviation safety.
"This issue has huge implications for our country and in particular for specific parts of our country," he said.
Under the Railway Labour Act, which also covers airlines, the president has the power to declare a national emergency to stop a strike and keep the planes flying.
Clinton, who made his comments in response to a question on whether he was inclined to declare a national emergency, did not tip his hand, saying only: "I have been following it very closely."
In November 1993, Clinton intervened to help end a strike by American Airlines' flight attendants when he successfully appealed to both sides to submit to arbitration.

Having failed to come to an agreement on their own, American, the nation's No. 2 carrier, and the Allied Pilots Association are negotiating under the auspices of a federal mediator. A strike by the 9,000 pilots would occur at midnight Friday unless a new contract can be reached.
Representatives of the two sides reached a tentative pact last September, but the pilots' rank-and-file rejected it in December, leading to the strike deadline and the federally mediated bargaining.
The two sides disagree on many issues, including pay.

An official at American, a unit of AMR Corp., said the airline had made a new proposal boosting its pay offer to a 6 percent raise over four years from 5 percent previously. The pilots want an 11.5 percent increase.

Although Clinton did not say what regions would be hardest hit by a strike, they would include Texas, Florida, Illinois and the New York metropolitan area since the Fort Worth-based carrier has major operations in Dallas-Fort Worth, Miami, Chicago and New York.
Senators from those regions met with top White House officials Wednesday to express their concerns about a possible strike.
Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Texas Republican, told reporters after the meeting that she had urged Clinton to "use all the powers and persuasion of the presidency" to facilitate a settlement.

Hutchison said the officials did not tip their hand in the meeting, adding, "I leave here believing the president will not do anything until time has run out for the parties to voluntarily come to a settlement."

Sen. Dick Durbin (corrects), an Illinois Democrat, said that it was his understanding from the meeting that Clinton "shares our watchful concern, but the burden is on the parties to come to an agreement before we even consider other alternatives."
